intro: Polygala carmichaelii, commonly known as the Carmichael's milkvetch, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of central and eastern China. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring slender, branching stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, delicate flowers in shades of pink to purple, arranged in clusters at the ends of the stems. Its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and often have a slightly hairy texture. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open woodlands or rocky habitats.
